text: Eric Jarvis
yes when I go to places I can't
recognize everybody so when I was 19
years old my father came back to live
with me and my grandfather for the first
time in ten years basically he was
living in caves doing some experiments
you have to understand my father was a
scientist of some sorts and he had some
unconventional ways about him and to
understand that you have to understand
my family history I was born in Harlem
that's where my parents lived their
parents came from the south during the
Great Depression years to to the great
city of New York and their ancestors
were basically slaves on the plantations
in the south the deep south african
american ancestors native american
actually for thousands of years
some European migrants in my family as
well and all through these generations
many generations has been a big struggle
in my family as there are in many
families from that kind of background
and my father in this you know 1900s
generation basically had some talents
and he was seen as a child prodigy who
was going to uplift the family out of
this many generations of economic and
psychological poverty and to understand
that for example my father had skipped
or was skipped two grades two different
grades during elementary school at the
age of ten he was trying to redo
Einstein's theory of relativity reprove
it at least he entered a high school of
music and art became a good pianist it
was a very good singer and at the age of
15 graduated high school and entered the
City University of New York
to become a chemist so you can imagine
the the expectations that were there so
while he was in college or soon around
that time he got married had four
children joined civil rights movements
joined the Black Panthers was the
nineteen sixties you see got into drugs
but he got into drugs in a different way
he actually you know in his chemist
training learned how to synthesize LSD
and cocaine and all the others yes and
and he also emerged himself in his own
experiments for example when I was his
child one day he sits me down on the
floor
cross-legged sits himself down but say
eight to eight what is this reel-to-reel
tape in between us and starts to proceed
to take these drugs like LSD and asked
me to observe him okay and to take notes
now I was just beginning to learn how to
write at this time I didn't know exactly
what to write he says well just remember
it and report back to me and I said why
what's what am I supposed to be looking
for he says well with these drugs so
theoretically supposedly your mind is
supposed to go to some other dimension
of time in space and he wanted to go to
this other dimension to try to capture
some of the fundamental laws of nature
and physics and I was supposed to be the
observer and in case I didn't catch
anything the eight to eight real tape
was supposed to record him and you know
well a six-year-old child doing this I I
was pretty fascinated and so so there
I'm watching I don't really see much
happening but it certainly got me
thinking and interested in in science
and even how the brain works then you
know wow the brain could really do this
to go to some other dimension of time
and space so my father was like this and
there were many other things about him
that really wasn't conducive to being a
you know typical father such that my
mother decided one day to pick up and
leave
with the four children and ever since
that time I had seen my father on and
off in coming in and out of our lives I
live with my grandparents and either
side of my family but really didn't see
him that much and eventually I got
interested in my own career
we were really pushed to pursue a career
early in life and I entered the High
School of Performing Arts in New York
City kind of following my father's steps
and my mother's as well she was a
musician and there I became a dancer I
actually went to the Alvin Ailey Dance
School dollar tschappat the Joffrey
Ballet as well and towards the end of my
high school years I was asked by the
Alvin Ailey school or company really can
i audition for the company so I thought
okay I'm doing relatively decently but I
really had an epiphany at that time and
I decided you know what am I going to
really do with my life and something
came to me that my mother always pushed
which was do something that has a
positive impact on society and I thought
I could do that as a scientist and I
knew something about science because of
my father's immersion into his ownself
and so I chose science once at a City
University of myself Hunter College and
in that first year while I was a
freshman one day I walk home well I come
back home living with my grandfather and
there was my father sitting in the
kitchen I was completely shocked because
you have to understand well you don't
understand but I'll tell you my
grandfather was the type of person who
grew up in the ghettos in the Bronx and
raised himself up from being a poor
african-american man to a person of you
know high respect district director or
customer director of customer services
for the New York City postal system and
he's considered my father who had all
this talent and destroyed it divorced
and so forth and got into drugs as a
failure and so he didn't really want my
father around and so why was my father
here
well it turns out that that time that he
came to live with us I asked what
happened well he had been living in
caves for the past six years now for
that six year period you have done one
thing that happened is that I would hear
people tell me I had seen your father in
Central Park homeless on the bench with
bags he looked like a bum and so this is
the vision that I had for that six year
period and here he is in my in my house
and so he said yes he was homeless but
he got tired of that type of living and
decided that one day he wanted to really
do something significant with his life
and so he picked up his bags his
belongings and began walking from the
Central Park mid Central Park to the end
of Central Park to the end of Manhattan
to upstate New York walking for two
weeks until he got to upstate New York
and found some caves to live in now he
was able to survive for that period of
time because he was trained as a Boy
Scout Troop
and so he fed himself by knowing which
berries and plants to eat from by
killing squirrels eating them he even
told me he saw a mountain lion one time
these are small Mountain mountain lions
that are upstate New York they actually
they exist up there and so and what was
his purpose his purpose was to
understand how did humans invent
civilization how did we come up with the
origins of language the origins of
religion he wanted to experience this
firsthand to make a discovery of how
religion and language evolved and the
only way he figured he was going to do
that was to experience it himself and so
you know I asked him a bunch of things
he learned for the sake of time I can't
go into everything but it would it was
amazing to me that I someone could
actually do this but he had to get back
into society
came back to the city but he didn't
quite come back to the city he went to
Inwood park where many you or many you
don't know there are some caves up there
as well some old ancient Indian caves
where he then ended up living as well in
Inwood park and Highbridge Park at the
tip of Manhattan in the meantime while
all this is going on my grandfather you
know had been saving up money from some
disability payments he was getting over
that 6-year period and my grandfather
saw my father just sitting around for
this one year even though I was talking
to him and so forth and just couldn't
stand it anymore
and told him he has to go back on his
own here's the $10,000 go find a place
to live my father took the $10,000 and
went on an Amtrak train trip around the
country to go see the La Brea Tar Pits
and the fossil remains there and so on
he came back to New York after that and
went back to the caves in Inwood park he
used to say to him apartments are just
caves on top of caves and people don't
really see what the real world is like
but he also said I don't know if my
psychosis belongs to me or the society
in which I live and so eventually he did
integrate partly back into society
living with assisted living route that
had shelter apartments for the homeless
in the meantime I go back to the lab and
I work feverishly spending the nights in
the lab doing lots of research I
published six papers as an undergraduate
student at Hunter College and even gave
my father one of them one time before he
had left and during that time I had you
know wondered what is happening to him
and eventually then I got into a
graduate school at the Rockefeller
University here in New York City and
began research towards my PhD and I was
thinking I'm going to make this I'm
going to not be the failure that my
father was and I'm going to succeed at
trying to do what I was doing and one
day when I came home from the lab
and I mind you I gotta tell you how hard
I worked actually to do my PhD thesis to
write it up I spent 30 days in the lab
sleeping there to finish that so in a
way the cave was my lab where the lab
was my cave I should say and so one day
I came home from my cave and while I'm
about to walk into the my door two
plainclothes detectives come up to me
and they asked me do you know James
Jarvis and I say yes that's my
grandfather why well he was killed
yesterday and I said no I I said no
that's not true I mean that my
grandfather he died six months earlier
and they said no no no this is a
different must be a different James
Jarvis because this is in six months ago
we're sure this was yesterday and they
pulled out an ID and I looked at it and
it was my father James Jarvis jr. and it
was pretty shocking to me at the time he
was 44 and I was 24 at the time and to
take put it all in perspective a number
of people had died in my family at the
time my father's of one of my father's
best friends from high school he was
shot a year earlier my uncle's had died
who my brother my grandfather's brothers
and so people were wondering who's going
to be next they thought it was going to
be me
and so then I proceeded to dig into my
father's life I've went to where he was
staying and found he had few possessions
but some one of the possessions that
really touched me most that he had
carried with him to the caves was my
first scientific publication and excuse
me and he had his Vox his fossils a few
of magazines a scientific American a
cutout from Scientific American magazine
that one day I asked them why were you
doing this and it was a rock it was a
round rock
on a cliff that hit the head of a
caveman sitting on another rock and said
duh the wheel the invention of the wheel
he wanted to figure out how that
happened and it turns out that he
apparently was killed by teenagers as a
gang initiation right sitting next to
one of the caves that he uses live in in
Highbridge Park and they the
investigators think that the teenagers
did not these teenagers did not value
the life of a person who looked like
they were homeless and so so after all
that happened and I you know tried to
overcome this and thinking in my necks
I've wondered am I going to make it is
it and my mother is also wondering this
and the rest of my family is wondering
this and so I proceeded to feverishly
again work in my laboratory now as a
graduate student before my time comes
and to accomplish what I'd like to do on
this planet before I leave
and ended up doing you know some decent
work made some discoveries about the
relationships of bird brains and music
with language brain pathways in us
eventually
also got a position at the rock of Duke
University Medical Center where I became
a professor and made some changes along
with the whole consortium of scientists
at bringing together our understanding
of the relationship of other animals and
us and showing that we are not so
different including like Alice gets bird
Irene Pepperberg fur Daleks and so all
during that time you know my father was
in me I realized because I would
actually take our work to the actual
environment so we discovered these song
learning brain areas and hummingbirds
and to do that we actually studied the
birds in the wild and study the genes
being regulated in those brains in wild
birds to find out they're actually
similar to brain
pathways for us for this speech what I'm
doing now so all that during that time I
was winning awards we were getting some
good recognition I finally felt
something is happening and recently I
got award at Duke University you know
they give it to one person a year and I
thought okay this is nice and you know
I'm making some milestones here although
I feel like we haven't really done what
I set out to do and the Chancellor of
the Medical Center comes to me during
the ceremony and says Eric I knew you're
gonna do something like this because
when I first interviewed you for the
medical school you were just so
unconventional you just did things
differently and and I kept thinking what
is different and I realize it's the way
my father had instilled that immersion
into your work into me so but the
milestone that I really think about now
happened this year this year I turned 44
and I never knew if I was gonna make it
and it's a really was a real struggle
for me and it's really the first time
I'm talking about it in front of this
group of people like this but I realized
that's my personal milestone that I have
given to myself and I just hope that
whenever we do something that has some
kind of impact then I can say that maybe
I am like my father to a certain degree
where I have one foot on the grid and
one foot off the grid and I don't know
if he would have done that what kind of
a you know contributions he would have
made the society but I really hope that
you know that we can do this and that
I'm going to be able to bring his legacy
further but with me and I thank you for
your attention
